title: Are You Losing Your Hair? What You Can Do About It

sections.heading: Types of Hair Loss
content: Since the dawn of time, hair has provided many uses and functions. Beyond keeping our heads warm, hair can be a form of self-expression, cultural identity, and a source of pride. When people experience hair loss, it can be both emotionally and physically devastating. Alopecia, the medical term for hair loss, is an umbrella term that encompasses many types of hair loss.

Hair loss has become a particular interest of mine. When patients come to see me, I feel a personal responsibility to provide them with options for hair preservation and restoration. Determining a person’s specific hair loss involves a detailed history, thorough hair and scalp exam, and occasionally, a scalp biopsy.
Here are some of the most common types of hair loss I see in my office.

This is also known as female or male patterned hair loss. It is a chronic condition that results in hair thinning distributed on the temples and/or crown of the scalp. This hair loss occurs when a naturally occurring hormone binds to receptors located on the scalp, which causes the hair to shrink and become thinner over time.

content: If left untreated, this condition will inevitably progress and result in slowed hair growth and eventual baldness. Treatments are aimed at both turning off the receptor activity and regrowing hair. Treatments like minoxidil is an excellent option for regrowing your hair. A recent study demonstrated oral and topical minoxidil has similar effectiveness in regrowing the hair and providing alternate options for pill-averse patients. Small studies have also demonstrated the effects of natural supplements like rosemary oil and saw palmetto.

This type of hair loss, which occurs on the crown of the scalp, is more common in women of African descent. A gene has been identified that results in activation of the immune system on the scalp. When activated, the immune system triggers inflammation and scar formation.

When untreated, the cyclical inflammation can cause scars to form around hair follicles and eventually lead to decreased hair growth over time. This shows up as shiny, bald spots on the scalp. Treatment is aimed at reducing the inflammation to prevent further hair loss. Depending on the severity of hair loss, treatments can range from topicals to oral medications.

content: Early intervention is key in preserving and restoring hair growth, so seeking immediate medical advice from a board-certified dermatologist helps keep your hair follicles healthy.
Recent studies have also identified associations with CCCA and uterine fibroids, which is also a common condition that disproportionately affects women of African descent.

Telogen effluvium is a type of non-scarring hair loss that oftentimes resolves with time.  It occurs when a stressful event, like rapid weight loss (think weight loss medicines), surgery, illnesses , or postpartum causes the body’s energy to shift, which can temporarily impact hair growth. The event typically occurs 3 months before the start of hair shedding and can take up to 6 months for the shedding to subside.
If you struggle with alopecia, I recommend consulting a board-certified dermatologist to discuss your specific needs and treatment goals.
